Riviera Maya

Mexico's Caribbean paradise — 100 miles of pristine beaches, ancient cenotes, and Mayan wonders

Quick Facts About Riviera Maya

Best Time to Visit
December - April
Average Temperature
28°C / 82°F
Known For
Beaches, Cenotes & Mayan Ruins
Airport Code
CUN

About Riviera Maya

The Riviera Maya stretches 100 miles along Mexico's Caribbean coast from Cancún to Tulum, offering pristine white-sand beaches, mysterious cenotes, world-class diving, ancient Mayan ruins, and everything from all-inclusive luxury to bohemian beach towns.

Neighborhoods in Riviera Maya

Explore the unique character of each neighborhood and find the perfect area for your stay.

    Vibe:

    The Riviera Maya's main hub with the famous 5th Avenue, beautiful beach clubs, international restaurants, and vibrant nightlife. Perfect base for exploring the region.

  • Riviera Maya

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Bohemian-chic beach strip with boutique hotels, beach clubs, cenotes, and the famous clifftop ruins. The Riviera Maya's most Instagram-worthy destination.

  • Riviera Maya

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Gated resort community with marina, dolphin experiences, and quiet beaches. Family-friendly with excellent all-inclusive options and water activities.

  • Riviera Maya

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Laid-back beach town famous for swimming with sea turtles. Less developed than Playa or Tulum with genuine small-town charm and beautiful half-moon bay.

  • Riviera Maya

    {{#if this.vibe}}

    Vibe:

    Charming fishing village with leaning lighthouse, excellent reef snorkeling, and authentic Mexican atmosphere. The quietest major town on the Riviera Maya.

    Explore multiple cenotes in one day: Dos Ojos for caves, Gran Cenote for turtles, Cenote Azul for families. The Riviera Maya has thousands to choose from.

  • Riviera Maya

    {{#if this.distance}}

    Distance:

    UNESCO-protected reserve with pristine beaches, ancient Mayan canals, and incredible wildlife. Float through channels the Maya built 1,000 years ago.

{{/if}}

Practical Information

Frequently Asked Questions About Riviera Maya

What's the difference between Cancún and the Riviera Maya?
Cancún is a specific city with its famous Hotel Zone on a narrow strip. The Riviera Maya is the 100-mile coastal stretch from Cancún south to Tulum, including Playa del Carmen, Puerto Morelos, Akumal, and Tulum. Cancún has more high-rise resorts and nightlife; the Riviera Maya offers more variety from boutique to all-inclusive, plus easier access to cenotes and ruins.
When is the best time to visit the Riviera Maya?
December to April offers the best weather with low humidity, minimal rain, and comfortable temperatures. May and November are good shoulder seasons with fewer crowds and good prices. Hurricane season runs June through November, with September and October having the highest risk.
How do I get around the Riviera Maya?
Colectivos (shared vans) run frequently between towns for $2-5 USD and are safe and efficient. Taxis and Uber work in main towns. Renting a car is best for exploring cenotes and ruins independently. Most all-inclusive guests stay at their resort, but renting a car for a day or two is recommended for exploration.
Is the Riviera Maya safe?
The tourist corridor is very safe. Millions visit annually without incident. Use normal precautions: don't leave valuables on the beach, use hotel safes, and stick to well-lit areas at night. The entire coast is well-patrolled. Petty theft is the main concern, not violent crime.
All-inclusive or independent hotels?
All-inclusives are great for families and those wanting zero hassle—everything's covered. Independent hotels (common in Tulum and Playa) offer more flexibility to explore local restaurants and nightlife. Many travelers do a mix: a few nights at an all-inclusive, then move to a boutique hotel.
What cenotes should I visit?
Gran Cenote near Tulum is perfect for beginners with easy access and turtles. Dos Ojos offers incredible cave snorkeling and diving. Cenote Azul is great for families with shallow areas. Cenote Suytun has dramatic light beams but gets crowded. Rent a car to visit multiple cenotes in a day.
Can I see Mayan ruins?
Yes! Tulum ruins are the most accessible, perched on cliffs above the beach. Cobá has the tallest climbable pyramid. Chichén Itzá is a day trip but worth it. Lesser-known sites like Ek Balam and Muyil offer ruins without crowds. Most resorts offer guided tours.
How many days should I spend?
7 days allows time for beaches, 2-3 cenotes, ruins, and relaxation. 10-14 days lets you explore multiple towns along the coast. Even 4-5 days can cover the highlights if you're efficient. For a deep dive into cenotes and ruins, plan 10+ days.
Is the water safe to drink?
No, don't drink tap water. All hotels provide purified water, and bottled water is cheap everywhere. Ice in restaurants is safe (made from purified water). Most resorts have filtered water dispensers. Avoid swallowing cenote water, though it looks pristine.
What about seaweed (sargassum)?
Sargassum seaweed has affected Caribbean beaches, especially from May to October. Resorts clean their beaches daily, but conditions vary. Check recent reports before booking. The west-facing beaches of Cozumel and Isla Mujeres are less affected.
